message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings suggest the most likely cause is Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS), which affects the small airways of the lungs. The small airways are lined with simple cuboidal cells, making option (D) the correct answer. Cartilage is present in the trachea and bronchi, while goblet cells and pseudostratified columnar cells are present in the larger airways of the lungs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest chronic rejection of the lung transplant, which is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration in the airway zone. Among the options, only simple cuboidal cells are present in the airway zone affected by this type of rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest chronic rejection of the lung allograft. The airway zone affected by chronic rejection of the lung allograft is typically characterized by the presence of simple cuboidal cells. Cartilage, goblet cells, and pseudostratified columnar cells may also be present, but they are not characteristically affected by chronic rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS), which is a common complication after lung transplantation. BOS affects the small airways of the lung, which consist of simple cuboidal cells. Therefore, the answer to this question is (D). Cartilage is present in the trachea and primary bronchi, goblet cells are present in the bronchial tree, and pseudostratified columnar cells are also found in the larger airways.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has had a lung transplant and is experiencing shortness of breath, suggesting some kind of graft dysfunction, possibly bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS). BOS affects the small airways, which consists of simple cuboidal cells. The other options are more characteristic of larger airways.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient with cystic fibrosis who had a lung transplant likely has chronic rejection, which is known to cause bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS). BOS affects the small airways, which are lined by simple cuboidal cells. Cartilage, goblet cells, and pseudostratified columnar cells are not typically found in the small airways affected by BOS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings suggest chronic rejection, which affects the small airways that are lined with simple cuboidal cells. None of the other options match the affected zone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. As the patient has had a lung transplant, the most likely cause of his symptoms is acute rejection. Acute rejection affects the small bronchioles, which are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. The other options are not typically affected in acute rejection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and biopsy results suggest chronic rejection of the lung transplant. The most likely affected airway zone is the small airways, which are lined with simple cuboidal cells. Cartilage is present in larger airways, while goblet cells and pseudostratified columnar cells are present throughout the respiratory tract.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy results suggest that the patient may have acute rejection after transplant. The most likely component affected is simple cuboidal cells in the airway zone. The immune system recognizes the transplanted organ as foreign, and the lymphocytic infiltration is a typical response to an organ rejection. Cartilage, goblet cells, and pseudostratified columnar cells may also be affected, but simple cuboidal cells are the most characteristic.
